member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.DisableRuntimeMarshallingAttribute
member.summary: Disables the built-in runtime managed/unmanaged marshalling subsystem for P/Invokes, Delegate types, and unmanaged function pointer invocations.
member.remarks:
The built-in marshalling subsystem has some behaviors that cannot be changed due to backward-compatibility requirements. This attribute allows disabling the built-in subsystem and instead uses the following rules for P/Invokes, Delegates, and unmanaged function pointer invocations:
- All value types that do not contain reference type fields recursively (unmanaged in C#) are blittable - Value types that recursively have any fields that have [StructLayout(LayoutKind.Auto)] are disallowed from interop. - All reference types are disallowed from usage in interop scenarios. - SetLastError support in P/Invokes is disabled. - varargs support is disabled. - LCIDConversionAttribute support is disabled.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RequiredMemberAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that a type has required members or that a member is required.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.SkipLocalsInitAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that the .locals init flag should not be set in method headers.
member.remarks: This attribute is unsafe because it may reveal uninitialized memory to the application in certain instances (e.g., reading from uninitialized stackalloc'd memory). If applied to a method directly, the attribute applies to that method and all nested functions (lambdas, local functions) below it. If applied to a type or module, it applies to all methods nested inside. This attribute is intentionally not permitted on assemblies. Use at the module level instead to apply to multiple type declarations.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.SupportedOSPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Records the operating system (and minimum version) that supports an API. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate support on multiple operating systems.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a or use guards to prevent calls to APIs on unsupported operating systems.
A given platform should only be specified once.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.SupportedOSPlatformGuardAttribute
member.summary: Annotates a custom guard field, property or method with a supported platform name and optional version. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate guard for multiple supported platforms.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a to a field, property or method and use that field, property or method in a conditional or assert statements in order to safely call platform specific APIs.
The type of the field or property should be boolean, the method return type should be boolean in order to be used as platform guard.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.TargetPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Records the platform that the project targeted.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.UnsupportedOSPlatformAttribute
member.summary: Marks APIs that were removed in a given operating system version.
member.remarks: Primarily used by OS bindings to indicate APIs that are only available in earlier versions.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.Versioning.UnsupportedOSPlatformGuardAttribute
member.summary: Annotates the custom guard field, property or method with an unsupported platform name and optional version. Multiple attributes can be applied to indicate guard for multiple unsupported platforms.
member.remarks:
Callers can apply a to a field, property or method and use that field, property or method in a conditional or assert statements as a guard to safely call APIs unsupported on those platforms.
The type of the field or property should be boolean, the method return type should be boolean in order to be used as platform guard.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.InteropServices.SuppressGCTransitionAttribute
member.summary: An attribute used to indicate a GC transition should be skipped when making an unmanaged function call.
member.remarks:
This attribute is ignored if applied to a method without the .
Forgoing this transition can yield benefits when the cost of the transition is more than the execution time of the unmanaged function. However, avoiding this transition removes some of the guarantees the runtime provides through a normal P/Invoke. When exiting the managed runtime to enter an unmanaged function the GC must transition from Cooperative mode into Preemptive mode. Full details on these modes can be found at https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/master/docs/coding-guidelines/clr-code-guide.md#2.1.8. Suppressing the GC transition is an advanced scenario and should not be done without fully understanding potential consequences.
One of these consequences is an impact to Mixed-mode debugging (https://docs.microsoft.com/visualstudio/debugger/how-to-debug-in-mixed-mode). During Mixed-mode debugging, it is not possible to step into or set breakpoints in a P/Invoke that has been marked with this attribute. A workaround is to switch to native debugging and set a breakpoint in the native function. In general, usage of this attribute is not recommended if debugging the P/Invoke is important, for example stepping through the native code or diagnosing an exception thrown from the native code.
The runtime may load the native library for method marked with this attribute in advance before the method is called for the first time. Usage of this attribute is not recommended for platform neutral libraries with conditional platform specific code.
The P/Invoke method that this attribute is applied to must have all of the following properties: * Native function always executes for a trivial amount of time (less than 1 microsecond). * Native function does not perform a blocking syscall (e.g. any type of I/O). * Native function does not call back into the runtime (e.g. Reverse P/Invoke). * Native function does not throw exceptions. * Native function does not manipulate locks or other concurrency primitives.
Consequences of invalid uses of this attribute: * GC starvation. * Immediate runtime termination. * Data corruption.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.InteropServices.UnmanagedCallersOnlyAttribute
member.summary: Any method marked with can be directly called from native code. The function token can be loaded to a local variable using the address-of operator in C# and passed as a callback to a native method.
member.remarks: Methods marked with this attribute have the following restrictions: * Method must be marked "static". * Must not be called from managed code. * Must only have blittable arguments.

member.remarks: Supplied types must be from the official "System.Runtime.CompilerServices" namespace and be of the form "CallConvXXX".

member.name: F:System.Runtime.InteropServices.UnmanagedCallersOnlyAttribute.EntryPoint
member.summary: Optional. If omitted, no named export is emitted during compilation.

member.param: The length of the collection that the Index will be used with. length has to be a positive value

member.remarks:
This allows tools to understand which members are being accessed during the execution of a program.
This attribute is valid on members whose type is or .
When this attribute is applied to a location of type , the assumption is that the string represents a fully qualified type name.
If the attribute is applied to a method it's treated as a special case and it implies the attribute should be applied to the "this" parameter of the method. As such the attribute should only be used on instance methods of types assignable to System.Type (or string, but no methods will use it there).

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Target
member.summary: Gets or sets a fully qualified path that represents the target of the attribute.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument identifying the analysis target of the attribute. An example value is "System.IO.Stream.ctor():System.Void". Because it is fully qualified, it can be long, particularly for targets such as parameters. The analysis tool user interface should be capable of automatically formatting the parameter.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.MessageId
member.summary: Gets or sets an optional argument expanding on exclusion criteria.
member.remarks: The property is an optional argument that specifies additional exclusion where the literal metadata target is not sufficiently precise. For example, the cannot be applied within a method, and it may be desirable to suppress a violation against a statement in the method that will give a rule violation, but not against all statements in the method.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnconditionalSuppressMessageAttribute.Justification
member.summary: Gets or sets the justification for suppressing the code analysis message.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

These can be either custom Instruments that you have created or any of the built-in metrics that are available.
See https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/diagnostics/built-in-metrics for more information.

member.name: M:Sentry.Internal.BackgroundWorker.EnqueueEnvelope(Sentry.Protocol.Envelopes.Envelope,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attempts to enqueue the envelope with the worker.
member.param: The envelope to enqueue.

Whether to process the next item in the queue after enqueuing this item, which may or may not be the item being enqueued. The default is true. Pass false for testing, when you want to add items to the queue without unblocking the worker. After items are enqueued, use to unblock the worker to process the items. Disposing the worker will also unblock the items, which will then be processed until the shutdown timeout is reached or the queue is emptied.
member.returns: True of queueing was successful. Otherwise, false.

member.param: The number of items to process from the queue.

member.name: M:Sentry.Internal.DebugStackTrace.DemangleAsyncFunctionName(Sentry.SentryStackFrame)
member.summary: Clean up function and module names produced from `async` state machine calls.
member.para: When the Microsoft cs.exe compiler compiles some modern C# features, such as async/await calls, it can create synthetic function names that do not match the function names in the original source code. Here we reverse some of these transformations, so that the function and module names that appears in the Sentry UI will match the function and module names in the original source-code.

member.summary: A cheap version of List(T). The idea is to make it as cheap as if you did it 'by hand' using an array and an int which represents the logical charCount. It is a struct to avoid an extra pointer dereference, so this is really meant to be embedded in other structures.
member.remarks: Adapted to null-safety from the original version licensed under MIT and located at: https://github.com/microsoft/perfview/blob/050c303943e74ff51ce584b2717e578d96684e85/src/FastSerialization/GrowableArray.cs

member.name: P:Sentry.Internal.GrowableArray`1.EmptyCapacity
member.summary: Returns true if the Growable array was initialized by the default constructor which has no capacity (and thus will cause growth on the first addition). This method allows you to lazily set the compacity of your GrowableArray by testing if it is of EmtpyCapacity, and if so set it to some useful capacity. This avoids unnecessary reallocs to get to a reasonable capacity.

member.name: F:Sentry.MetricHelper.FlushShift
member.summary: The aggregator shifts it's flushing by up to an entire rollup window to avoid multiple clients trampling on end of a 10 second window as all the buckets are anchored to multiples of ROLLUP seconds. We randomize this number once per aggregator boot to achieve some level of offsetting across a fleet of deployed SDKs. Relay itself will also apply independent jittering.
member.remarks: Internal for testing

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Device.ProcessorFrequency
member.summary: Processor frequency in MHz. Note that the actual CPU frequency might vary depending on current load and power conditions, especially on low-powered devices like phones and laptops. On some platforms it's not possible to query the CPU frequency. Currently such platforms are iOS and WebGL.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Device.DeviceType
member.summary: Kind of device the application is running on.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Device.BatteryStatus
member.summary: Status of the device's battery.

members.member:
Unique device identifier. Depends on the running platform.
iOS: UIDevice.identifierForVendor (UUID) Android: The generated Installation ID Windows Store Apps: AdvertisingManager::AdvertisingId (possible fallback to HardwareIdentification::GetPackageSpecificToken().Id) Windows Standalone: hash from the concatenation of strings taken from Computer System Hardware Classes
TODO: Investigate - Do ALL platforms now return a generated installation ID? See https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-java/pull/1455

member.name: T:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism
member.summary: Sentry Exception Mechanism.
member.remarks: The exception mechanism is an optional field residing in the Exception Interface. It carries additional information about the way the exception was created on the target system. This includes general exception values obtained from operating system or runtime APIs, as well as mechanism-specific values.

member.name: F:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.HandledKey
member.summary: Key found inside of Exception.Data to inform if the exception was handled.

member.name: F:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.MechanismKey
member.summary: Key found inside of Exception.Data to inform which mechanism captured the exception.

member.name: F:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.DescriptionKey
member.summary: Key found inside of Exception.Data to provide a description of the mechanism.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Type
member.summary: Required unique identifier of this mechanism determining rendering and processing of the mechanism data. Defaults to "generic".
member.remarks: If null, empty, or whitespace are set, reverts to the default string "generic". Nullability is for backwards compatibility, and may be removed in a future major version.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Description
member.summary: Optional human readable description of the error mechanism and a possible hint on how to solve this error.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Source
member.summary: An optional value to explain the source of the exception.
member.remarks: For chained exceptions, this should be the property name where the exception was retrieved from its parent exception. In .NET, either "" or "InnerExceptions[i]" (where i is replaced with the numeric index within ).

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.HelpLink
member.summary: Optional fully qualified URL to an online help resource, possible interpolated with error parameters.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Handled
member.summary: Optional flag indicating whether the exception has been handled by the user (e.g. via try..catch).

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Synthetic
member.summary: Optional flag indicating whether the exception is synthetic.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.IsExceptionGroup
member.summary: Whether the exception represents an exception group. In .NET, an .

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.ExceptionId
member.summary: A numeric identifier assigned to the exception by the SDK.
member.remarks: The SDK should assign a different ID to each exception in an event, starting with the root exception as 0, and incrementing thereafter. This ID can be used with to reconstruct the logical structure of an exception group. When null, Sentry will assume that all exceptions in an event are in a single chain.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.ParentId
member.summary: The parent exception's identifier, or null for the root exception.
member.remarks: This ID can be used with to reconstruct the logical structure of an exception group.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Meta
member.summary: Optional information from the operating system or runtime on the exception mechanism.
member.remarks: The mechanism meta data usually carries error codes reported by the runtime or operating system, along with a platform dependent interpretation of these codes. SDKs can safely omit code names and descriptions for well known error codes, as it will be filled out by Sentry. For proprietary or vendor-specific error codes, adding these values will give additional information to the user.

member.name: P:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.Data
member.summary: Arbitrary extra data that might help the user understand the error thrown by this mechanism.

member.name: M:Sentry.Protocol.Mechanism.FromJson(System.Text.Json.JsonElement)
member.summary: Parses from JSON.

member.remarks: Scope data is sent together with any event captured during the lifetime of the scope.

member.summary: Whether the event has already fired.

member.summary: A list of exception processors.

member.summary: A list of event processors.

member.summary: A list of event processors.

member.name: E:Sentry.Scope.OnEvaluating
member.summary: An event that fires when the scope evaluates.
member.remarks: This allows registering an event handler that is invoked in case an event is about to be sent to Sentry. If an event is never sent, this event is never fired and the resources spared. It also allows registration at an early stage of the processing but execution at a later time, when more data is available.

summary.para: Most of the properties on the Scope should have the same affinity as the Scope... For example, when using a GlobalScopeStackContainer, anything you store on the scope will be applied to all events that get sent to Sentry (no matter which thread they are sent from).

Transactions are an exception, however. We don't want spans from threads created on the UI thread to be added as children of Transactions/Spans that get created on the background thread, or vice versa. As such, Scope.Transaction is always stored as an AsyncLocal, regardless of the ScopeStackContainer implementation.
See https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-dotnet/issues/3590 for more information.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.Release

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.Distribution
member.summary: The distribution of the application, associated with the release set in .
member.remarks: Distributions are used to disambiguate build or deployment variants of the same release of an application. For example, it can be the build number of an XCode (iOS) build, or the version code of an Android build. A distribution can be set under any circumstances, and is passed along to Sentry if provided. However, they are generally relevant only for mobile application scenarios.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.Environment

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.ShutdownTimeout
member.summary: How long to wait for events to be sent before shutdown
member.remarks: In case there are events queued when the SDK is closed, upper bound limit to wait for the worker to send the events to Sentry.
member.example: The SDK is closed while the queue has 1 event queued. The worker takes 50 milliseconds to send an event to Sentry. Even though default settings say 2 seconds, closing the SDK would block for 50ms.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.RequestBodyCompressionBuffered
member.summary: Whether the body compression is buffered and the request 'Content-Length' known in advance.
member.remarks: Without reading through the Gzip stream to have its final size, it's no possible to use 'Content-Length' header value. That means 'Content-Encoding: chunked' has to be used which is sometimes not supported. Sentry on-premise without a reverse-proxy, for example, does not support 'chunked' requests.

summary.para: The SDK will only capture HTTP Client errors if it is enabled.
can be used to configure which requests will be treated as failed.
Also can be used to filter to match only certain request URLs.
Defaults to true.
The SDK will only capture HTTP Client errors if the HTTP Response status code is within these defined ranges.
Defaults to 500-599 (Server error responses only).
The SDK will only capture HTTP Client errors if the HTTP Request URL is a match for any of the failedRequestsTargets.
Targets may be URLs or Regular expressions.
Matches "*." by default.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.FileSystem
member.summary: Sets the filesystem instance to use. Defaults to the actual . Used for testing.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.DisableFileWrite
member.summary: Allows to disable the SDKs writing to disk operations

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.InitCacheFlushTimeout
member.summary: If set to a positive value, Sentry will attempt to flush existing local event cache when initializing. Set to to disable this feature. This option only works if is configured as well.
member.remarks: The trade off here is: Ensure a crash that happens during app start is sent to Sentry even though that might slow down the app start. If set to false, the app might crash too quickly, before Sentry can capture the cached error in the background.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.DefaultTags
member.summary: Defaults tags to add to all events. (These are indexed by Sentry).

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.IsPerformanceMonitoringEnabled
member.summary: Indicates whether the performance feature is enabled, via either or .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.IsProfilingEnabled
member.summary: Indicates whether profiling is enabled, via , or

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.TracesSampleRate
member.summary:
Indicates the percentage of the tracing data that is collected.
Value Effect
>= 0.0 and <=1.0
A custom sample rate is used unless overriden by a function. Values outside of this range are invalid.
null
The default setting. The tracing sample rate is determined by the function.
member.remarks: Random sampling rate is only applied to transactions that don't already have a sampling decision set by other means, such as through , by inheriting it from an incoming trace header, or by copying it from .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.ProfilesSampleRate
member.summary:
The sampling rate for profiling is relative to . Setting to 1.0 will profile 100% of sampled transactions.
Value Effect
>= 0.0 and <=1.0
A custom sample rate is. Values outside of this range are invalid. Setting to 0.0 will disable profiling.
null
The default setting. At this time, this is equivalent to 0.0, i.e. disabling profiling, but that may change in the future.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.TracesSampler
member.summary: Custom delegate that returns sample rate dynamically for a specific transaction context.
member.remarks: Returning null signals that the sampler did not reach a sampling decision. In such case, if the transaction already has a sampling decision (for example, if it's started from a trace header) that decision is retained. Otherwise sampling decision is determined by applying the static sampling rate set in .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.TracePropagationTargets
member.summary: A customizable list of objects, each containing either a substring or regular expression pattern that can be used to control which outgoing HTTP requests will have the sentry-trace, traceparent, and baggage headers propagated, for purposes of distributed tracing. The default value contains a single value of .*, which matches everything. To disable propagation completely, clear this collection or set it to an empty collection.
member.remarks: Adding an item to the default list will clear the .* value automatically.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.StackTraceMode
member.summary: ATTENTION: This option will change how issues are grouped in Sentry!
member.remarks: Sentry groups events by stack traces. If you change this mode and you have thousands of groups, you'll get thousands of new groups. So use this setting with care.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.MaxAttachmentSize
member.summary: Maximum allowed file size of attachments, in bytes. Attachments above this size will be discarded.
member.remarks: Regardless of this setting, attachments are also limited to 20mb (compressed) on Relay.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.DetectStartupTime
member.summary: The mode that the SDK should use when attempting to detect the app's and device's startup time.
member.remarks: Note that the highest precision value relies on which might not be available. For example on Unity's IL2CPP or WebAssembly. Additionally, "Best" mode is not available on mobile platforms.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.AutoSessionTrackingInterval
member.summary: Determines the duration of time a session can stay paused before it's considered ended.
member.remarks: Note: This interval is only taken into account when integrations support Pause and Resume.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.AutoSessionTracking
member.summary: Whether the SDK should start a session automatically when it's initialized and end the session when it's closed.
member.remarks: Currently, this only works for release health in client mode (desktop, mobile applications, but not web servers) as this feature requires access to the filesystem to sync sessions and multiple instances of the app will race each other.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.UseAsyncFileIO
member.summary: Whether the SDK should attempt to use asynchronous file I/O. For example, when reading a file to use as an attachment.
member.remarks: This option should rarely be disabled, but is necessary in some environments such as Unity WebGL.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.CrashedLastRun
member.summary: Delegate which is used to check whether the application crashed during last run.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.JsonPreserveReferences
member.summary: When true, if an object being serialized to JSON contains references to other objects, and the serialized object graph exceed the maximum allowable depth, the object will instead be serialized using (from System.Text.Json) - which adds $id and $ref metadata to the JSON. When false, an object graph exceeding the maximum depth will be truncated. The default value is true.
member.remarks: This option applies only to complex objects being added to Sentry events as contexts or extras, which do not implement .

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.NetworkStatusListener
member.summary: Provides a mechanism to convey network status to the caching transport, so that it does not attempt to send cached events to Sentry when the network is offline. Used internally by some integrations. Not intended for public usage.
member.remarks: This must be public because we use it in Sentry.Maui, which can't use InternalsVisibleTo because MAUI assemblies are not strong-named.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryOptions.AssemblyReader
member.summary: Allows integrations to provide a custom assembly reader.
member.remarks: This is for Sentry use only, and can change without a major version bump.

member.name: M:Sentry.SentryOptions.AddInAppExclude(System.Text.RegularExpressions.Regex)
member.summary: Add a regex to identify frames that are not 'InApp' in stacktraces. It will usually be more convenient to use the method, however you can use this overload if you want to control the used when constructing the Regular Expression. For performance reasons, it's recommend that you use when creating the regex and unless you have specific reason consider using as well.
member.param: The regular expression to use to match stacktrace frames.
member.remarks: Sentry by default filters the stacktrace to display only application code. A user can optionally click to see all which will include framework and libraries. If a frame has not already been determined to be InApp per any of the prefixes or patterns configured in , it will be considered InApp only if it does not match any of the prefixes or patterns in .

member.name: M:Sentry.SentrySdk.Init
member.summary: Initializes the SDK while attempting to locate the DSN.
member.remarks: If the DSN is not found, the SDK will not change state.
member.returns: An object that can be disposed to disable the Sentry SDK, if desired.
member.remarks:
Disposing the result will flush previously-captured events and disable the SDK. In most cases there's no need to dispose the result. There are only a few exceptions where it makes sense to dispose:
You have additional work to perform that you don't want Sentry to monitor.
You have used .
You are integrating Sentry into an environment that has custom application lifetime events.

member.summary: Adds a breadcrumb to the current Scope.
member.param: If a message is provided its rendered as text and the whitespace is preserved. Very long text might be abbreviated in the UI.

Categories are dotted strings that indicate what the crumb is or where it comes from. Typically its a module name or a descriptive string. For instance ui.click could be used to indicate that a click happened in the UI or flask could be used to indicate that the event originated in the Flask framework.
The type of breadcrumb. The default type is default which indicates no specific handling. Other types are currently http for HTTP requests and navigation for navigation events.
Data associated with this breadcrumb. Contains a sub-object whose contents depend on the breadcrumb type. Additional parameters that are unsupported by the type are rendered as a key/value table.
Breadcrumb level.

member.summary: The column number of the call.

member.summary: The absolute path to filename.

member.summary: Source code in filename at line number.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.PreContext
member.summary: A list of source code lines before context_line (in order) usually [lineno - 5:lineno].

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.PostContext
member.summary: A list of source code lines after context_line (in order) usually [lineno + 1:lineno + 5].

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.InApp
member.summary: Signifies whether this frame is related to the execution of the relevant code in this stacktrace.
member.example: For example, the frames that might power the frameworks web server of your app are probably not relevant, however calls to the frameworks library once you start handling code likely are.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Vars
member.summary: A mapping of variables which were available within this frame (usually context-locals).

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.FramesOmitted
member.summary: Which frames were omitted, if any.
member.remarks: If the list of frames is large, you can explicitly tell the system that youve omitted a range of frames. The frames_omitted must be a single tuple two values: start and end.
member.example: If you only removed the 8th frame, the value would be (8, 9), meaning it started at the 8th frame, and went until the 9th (the number of frames omitted is end-start). The values should be based on a one-index.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Package
member.summary: The assembly where the code resides.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.Platform
member.summary: This can override the platform for a single frame. Otherwise the platform of the event is assumed.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.ImageAddress
member.summary: Optionally an address of the debug image to reference. If this is set and a known image is defined by debug_meta then symbolication can take place.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.SymbolAddress
member.summary: An optional address that points to a symbol. We actually use the instruction address for symbolication but this can be used to calculate an instruction offset automatically.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.InstructionAddress
member.summary:
An optional instruction address for symbolication.
If this is set and a known image is defined in the Debug Meta Interface, then symbolication can take place.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.AddressMode
member.summary: Optionally changes the addressing mode. The default value is the same as `"abs"` which means absolute referencing. This can also be set to `"rel:DEBUG_ID"` or `"rel:IMAGE_INDEX"` to make addresses relative to an object referenced by debug id or index.

member.name: P:Sentry.SentryStackFrame.FunctionId
member.summary:
The optional Function Id.
This is derived from the `MetadataToken`, and should be the record id of a `MethodDef`.

member.name: T:Sentry.InstructionAddressAdjustment
member.summary: Instruction Address Adjustments

member.name: F:Sentry.InstructionAddressAdjustment.Auto
member.summary: Symbolicator will use the `"all_but_first"` strategy **unless** the event has a crashing `signal` attribute and the Stack Trace has a `registers` map, and the instruction pointer register (`rip` / `pc`) does not match the first frame. In that case, `"all"` frames will be adjusted.

member.name: F:Sentry.InstructionAddressAdjustment.All
member.summary: All frames of the stack trace will be adjusted, subtracting one instruction with (or `1`) from the incoming `instruction_addr` before symbolication.

member.name: F:Sentry.InstructionAddressAdjustment.AllButFirst
member.summary: All frames but the first (in callee to caller / child to parent direction) should be adjusted.

member.name: F:Sentry.InstructionAddressAdjustment.None
member.summary: No adjustment will be applied whatsoever.

member.name: P:Sentry.W3CTraceHeader.SentryTraceHeader
member.summary: Gets the Sentry trace header containing trace identification and sampling information.
member.value: The Sentry trace header that contains the trace ID, span ID, and sampling decision.

member.name: M:Sentry.W3CTraceHeader.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a from a string representation of the Sentry trace header.
member.param: A string containing the Sentry trace header, expected to follow the format "traceId-spanId-sampled", where "sampled" is optional.
member.returns: A object if parsing succeeds, or null if the input string is null, empty, or whitespace.
member.exception: Thrown if the input string does not contain a valid trace header format, specifically if it lacks required trace ID and span ID components.
